segments.title: Definition of Density
segments.summary: Density is explained as the ratio of mass to volume, measured in kg/m³. It represents how crowded or packed something is, with examples given for water (1000 kg/m³) and iron (7.8 g/cm³).

segments.title: Density and Floating
segments.summary: Objects with lower density than water tend to float, while those with higher density sink. This principle explains why oil floats on water and iron sinks.

segments.title: Temperature Effects on Density
segments.summary: The density of water varies with temperature, reaching maximum density at 4°C at 1 g/cm³. As temperature decreases, molecules generally come closer together, increasing density.

segments.title: Air Density Variation
segments.summary: The density of air varies with altitude due to the weight of the atmosphere above. Lower layers experience more pressure, resulting in higher density at lower altitudes.

segments.title: Water Density Properties
segments.summary: Unlike gases, water is nearly incompressible, maintaining consistent density despite high pressure variations in oceans. Even extreme pressures at ocean depths don't significantly change water's density.
